Interacting with GitHub using githubr

Luke W. Johnston

2019-02-27

Source: vignettes/githubr.Rmd
githubr.Rmd

The githubr package is primarily a wrapper around the great gh package to create functions for explicit and simple calls to the API. For instance, if you want to create a new issue to a repository, you can use the function gh_new_issue() rather than tinkering through the GitHub API. The arguments to the functions provide (almost) everything you need when interacting with GitHub! Currently, githubr (and by extension the gh package it is based on) uses the v3 of the API.

The main purpose for this package is to programmatically interact with GitHub activities, such as quickly creating issues for multiple problems, deleting labels and using other labels (e.g. less software focused), or making edits to existing issues.

A big assumption about using githubr is that you are authenticated with GitHub via a Personal Access Token.

Authenticating: Obtaining a GitHub PAT

Before you can really start using githubr, you need to get authenticated with GitHub. Nearly all githubr functions require a GitHub PAT, or Personal Access Token. The PAT is obtained through a GITHUB_PAT R environment variable and can be found by using:

gh::gh_whoami()

If you have it set up, you should see a "token" key-value pair. For more information about PAT, how to get one, and how to set it up in R, check out the usethis::browse_github_pat(). Do this in order to fully make use of the githubr functions.

Functions implemented

The GitHub API is extensive, so not all functions have (or will be) implemented to fully interact with GitHub. If you want to make an API request for items not listed in the two tables below, head over to the gh package to be able to do what you want.

Implemented githubr functions.
Name Description
gh_create_label Create a GitHub label for a repository.
gh_delete_label Delete a GitHub label.
gh_list_issues List issues in GitHub repository.
gh_list_labels List labels in a GitHub repository.
gh_list_user_orgs List GitHub organizations an user is a member of.
gh_new_issue Create a GitHub issue in a repository.
gh_new_repo Create either a personal or organization repository.
tidy Convert a ‘gh_response’ object to a tidied data.frame.

Creating, editing, and listing issues

Working with issues is easy! Have a repository and you want to see what issues are available?

library(githubr)
gh_list_issues("lwjohnst86/carpenter")
#> # A tibble: 13 x 11
#>    state number title labels.name body  milestone.number milestone.title
#>    <chr> <chr>  <chr> <chr>       <chr> <chr>            <chr>          
#>  1 open  25     Remo… question    ""    <NA>             <NA>           
#>  2 open  24     Add … docs        ""    1                v0.3.0         
#>  3 open  23     Add … docs        To Z… 1                v0.3.0         
#>  4 open  21     Crea… feature     ""    1                v0.3.0         
#>  5 open  20     Func… feature     For … 1                v0.3.0         
#>  6 open  19     Add … feature     ""    1                v0.3.0         
#>  7 open  17     Add … feature     ""    1                v0.3.0         
#>  8 open  16     Use … feature     ""    <NA>             <NA>           
#>  9 open  15     Have… feature     Inst… 1                v0.3.0         
#> 10 open  14     Chan… feature     This… 1                v0.3.0         
#> 11 open  9      Use … feature     Simi… 1                v0.3.0         
#> 12 open  2      Add … <NA>        ""    <NA>             <NA>           
#> 13 open  1      Add … <NA>        ""    <NA>             <NA>           
#> # … with 4 more variables: milestone.open_issues <chr>,
#> #   milestone.closed_issues <chr>, milestone.state <chr>, comments <chr>

What about checking out all the labels?

repository <- "lwjohnst86/test-githubr"
gh_list_labels(repository)
#> # A tibble: 9 x 2
#>   name                color 
#>   <chr>               <chr> 
#> 1 bug                 d73a4a
#> 2 duplicate           cfd3d7
#> 3 enhancement         a2eeef
#> 4 feature request     ededed
#> 5 good first issue    7057ff
#> 6 help wanted         008672
#> 7 invalid             e4e669
#> 8 question :question: d876e3
#> 9 wontfix             ffffff

You can even add another label (and delete it if you want).

gh_create_label(repository, "Interesting", "deadad")
gh_list_labels(repository)
#> # A tibble: 10 x 2
#>    name                color 
#>    <chr>               <chr> 
#>  1 Interesting         deadad
#>  2 bug                 d73a4a
#>  3 duplicate           cfd3d7
#>  4 enhancement         a2eeef
#>  5 feature request     ededed
#>  6 good first issue    7057ff
#>  7 help wanted         008672
#>  8 invalid             e4e669
#>  9 question :question: d876e3
#> 10 wontfix             ffffff

# Then delete it
gh_delete_label(repository, "Interesting")
gh_list_labels(repository)
#> # A tibble: 9 x 2
#>   name                color 
#>   <chr>               <chr> 
#> 1 bug                 d73a4a
#> 2 duplicate           cfd3d7
#> 3 enhancement         a2eeef
#> 4 feature request     ededed
#> 5 good first issue    7057ff
#> 6 help wanted         008672
#> 7 invalid             e4e669
#> 8 question :question: d876e3
#> 9 wontfix             ffffff

Want to create a new issue? Easy too!

gh_new_issue(repository, title = "Making an issue", labels = c("bug", "wontfix"))
head(gh_list_issues(repository), 1)
#> # A tibble: 1 x 7
#>   state number title           labels.name labels.name.1 body  comments
#>   <chr> <chr>  <chr>           <chr>       <chr>         <chr> <chr>   
#> 1 open  25     Making an issue bug         wontfix       <NA>  0

Functions to be implemented

There are of course several functions that will eventually be implemented. Here is a list of functions planned to be implemented at some point in the future.

Functions to still implement in githubr.
Name Description
gh_close_issue Close a GitHub repository’s issue.
gh_close_pull_request Close a currently open GitHub Pull Request.
gh_delete_all_labels Delete all labels from a GitHub repository.
gh_delete_release Delete a GitHub release.
gh_edit_issue Edit parts of a GitHub repository’s issue.
gh_edit_pull_request Make edits to existing GitHub Pull Requests.
gh_edit_release Edits an existing GitHub release.
gh_edit_repo Edit GitHub repository details and settings.
gh_list_pull_requests List all Pull Requests in a GitHub repository.
gh_list_releases List all releases in a GitHub repository.
gh_list_tags List all tags in a GitHub repository.
gh_new_pull_request Create a GitHub pull request.
gh_new_release Create a release of a Git tag.
